verses.text: After this, the Lord appointed seventy-two others and sent them ahead of him, two by two, into every town and place where he himself was about to go.
verses.comment: Jesus's sending of seventy-two foreshadows universal mission, connecting to Moses appointing elders (Ex. 18). The number “seventy-two” signifies fullness and inclusiveness, not just the twelve apostles. This hints at a structured, hierarchical, and worldwide mission of the Church.

verses.text: He told them, 'The harvest is plentiful, but the laborers are few. Therefore, ask the Lord of the harvest to send out laborers into his harvest.'
verses.comment: Jesus calls for prayer for more workers, emphasizing dependence on God's initiative and the abundant scope of the mission. The reference to harvest shows God's desire for salvation for all, fulfilled most perfectly in a united Church.

verses.text: 'Go! I am sending you out like lambs among wolves.'
verses.comment: Jesus’s followers are called to be meek and vulnerable yet entrusted with authority. This echoes Isaiah’s Suffering Servant, pointing to Christ’s own mission and laying a pattern for his Church’s missionary work.

verses.text: 'Carry no purse, no bag, no sandals, and greet no one on the road.'
verses.comment: This shows radical trust in Divine Providence. The instruction to not greet emphasizes urgency—the apostolic mission takes priority, reflecting a self-giving posture of service similar to the prophets.

verses.text: 'Whenever you enter a house, first say, Peace to this house.'
verses.comment: The greeting of peace is both a blessing and a sign of God’s presence. Compare this with Christ’s post-resurrection greeting: peace is a mark of divine reconciliation.

verses.text: 'If a son of peace is there, your peace will rest upon him; but if not, it will return to you.'
verses.comment: The idea of peace returning points to a spiritual reality: God’s blessings are not wasted—true communion is reciprocal and enduring. This unity prefigures the coming together of God’s people.

verses.text: 'Remain in that same house, eating and drinking whatever they provide, for the laborer deserves his wages. Do not move from house to house.'
verses.comment: Jesus teaches stability, hospitality, and rightful support for ministers of the faith, giving foundations for the later understanding of clergy support and belonging to a single community.

verses.text: 'Whenever you enter a town and they welcome you, eat what is set before you.'
verses.comment: The mission transcends ritual purity laws. Openness to all, regardless of background, points to the inclusive and universal nature of the faith.

verses.text: 'Heal the sick who are there, and say to them, The kingdom of God has come near to you.'
verses.comment: Physical healing accompanies spiritual proclamation. The coming kingdom is both present and imminent, ushered in through Jesus and his appointed servants.

verses.text: 'But whenever you enter a town and they do not welcome you, go out into its streets and say,'
verses.comment: Rejection of the Lord’s messengers reflects rejection of the Lord himself, highlighting the importance of visible unity and acceptance within the faith community.

verses.text: 'Even the dust of your town that clings to our feet we wipe off against you. Yet know this, the kingdom of God has come near.'
verses.comment: Shaking off the dust symbolizes discontinuity—separation from those who resist the fullness of God’s revelation. The kingdom’s nearness demands decision and conversion.

verses.text: 'I tell you, it will be more bearable on that day for Sodom than for that town.'
verses.comment: Judgment is harsher for those who reject direct revelation of the Messiah’s kingdom, implying that visible, sacramental encounter with the faith is crucial for salvation.

verses.text: 'Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida! For if the mighty works done in you had been done in Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago, sitting in sackcloth and ashes.'
verses.comment: Greater responsibility follows greater revelation. Those who encounter Christ through tangible means are called to deep conversion.

verses.text: 'But it will be more bearable for Tyre and Sidon at the judgment than for you.'
verses.comment: Responsibility increases with the closeness to Christ’s works, underscoring connection to visible structures and leaders established by Jesus.

verses.text: 'And you, Capernaum, will you be exalted to heaven? No, you will be brought down to Hades.'
verses.comment: Pride separates one from grace. True exaltation comes only through humble reception of Christ and his appointed Church.

verses.text: 'Whoever hears you hears me, and whoever rejects you rejects me; and whoever rejects me rejects him who sent me.'
verses.comment: Here Jesus explicitly ties himself into the authority of his emissaries. Their teaching and judgment are his own, setting a precedent for authoritative teachers and unity in the Church.

verses.text: The seventy-two returned with joy, saying, 'Lord, even the demons submit to us in your name!'
verses.comment: The invocation of ‘in your name’ reveals the power of Christ’s personal authority, received by his ministers. This demonstrates the delegated but real authority present in the Church.

verses.text: He replied to them, 'I saw Satan fall like lightning from heaven.'
verses.comment: Jesus references a cosmic victory over evil, showing divine authority. This also points to the ongoing spiritual battle and the reality of evil’s defeat through Christ’s Church.

verses.text: 'See, I have given you authority to tread on serpents and scorpions, and over all the power of the enemy, and nothing will ever harm you.'
verses.comment: Symbolic of spiritual authority and victory over evil, the apostles inherit Christ’s power—a model for enduring and visible guidance.

verses.text: 'Nevertheless, do not rejoice that the spirits submit to you, but rejoice that your names are written in heaven.'
verses.comment: True joy is found not in miracles but in participation in communion with God—an eternal membership recorded in heaven.

verses.text: At that same hour, Jesus rejoiced greatly in the Holy Spirit and said, 'I thank you, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, that you have hidden these things from the wise and learned and have revealed them to little children. Yes, Father, for such was your gracious will.'
verses.comment: Here Jesus is depicted in intimate unity with the Father and the Spirit – an implicit claim to divinity and illustration of Trinitarian mystery.

verses.text: 'All things have been handed over to me by my Father, and no one knows who the Son is except the Father, and who the Father is except the Son and anyone to whom the Son chooses to reveal him.'
verses.comment: A profound statement of Christ’s divinity; knowledge of the Father is only through the Son. This ties into the necessity of being united to Christ’s visible body for full revelation.

verses.text: Then, turning to the disciples apart, he said, 'Blessed are the eyes that see what you see!'
verses.comment: Direct encounter with Christ is a unique priviliege. The visible community founded by Christ joins all believers in his blessing.

verses.text: 'For I tell you, many prophets and kings desired to see what you see and did not see it, and to hear what you hear and did not hear it.'
verses.comment: Direct fulfillment of Old Testament longing. Christ’s presence fulfills prophecy, making visible his salvation in tangible historical ways.

verses.text: And behold, a certain lawyer stood up to test him, saying, 'Teacher, what must I do to inherit eternal life?'
verses.comment: The question of eternal life is central; Jesus is depicted as the source and authoritative guide for salvation.

verses.text: He said to him, 'What is written in the Law? How do you read it?'
verses.comment: Jesus affirms the authority of Scripture, prompting an interpretation that hinges on more than letter but deeper spiritual meaning.

verses.text: And he answered, 'You shall love the Lord your God with all your heart, with all your soul, with all your strength, and with all your mind; and your neighbor as yourself.'
verses.comment: This summary of the Law shows that true fulfillment is spiritual as well as practical: loving God and neighbor as one united family.

verses.text: And he said to him, 'You have answered correctly; do this and you will live.'
verses.comment: Living out the faith means concrete action, not just words—obedience within community. This relates to the ongoing call for visible signs of commitment.

verses.text: But he, wanting to justify himself, said to Jesus, 'And who is my neighbor?'
verses.comment: The human tendency to restrict love is challenged by Christ’s teaching which opens the boundaries of God’s family.

verses.text: Jesus replied, 'A certain man was going down from Jerusalem to Jericho, and fell among robbers, who stripped him, beat him, and departed, leaving him half dead.'
verses.comment: The setting connects Jerusalem (where God dwells) to the world’s brokenness. The parable prefigures Christ’s own work of rescue and healing.

verses.text: By chance, a priest was going down that way. When he saw him, he passed by on the other side.
verses.comment: The priest’s avoidance highlights the insufficiency of ritual without mercy, suggesting that perfection comes from both worship and charity.

verses.text: Likewise, a Levite, when he arrived at the place and saw him, passed by on the other side.
verses.comment: Similar avoidance by the Levite. True faith is manifest in love and healing of others, not only in ritual or heritage.

verses.text: But a certain Samaritan, as he journeyed, came to where he was; and when he saw him, he was moved with compassion.
verses.comment: Outsiders unexpectedly embody the heart of God’s law. This foreshadows the mission opening to all nations, yet fulfilled in unity around visible leaders.

verses.text: He went to him, bound up his wounds, pouring on oil and wine. Then he set him on his own animal, brought him to an inn, and took care of him.
verses.comment: Oil and wine have sacramental overtones—symbols of healing and the gifts of the Church. The inn hints at the house of God, a place of restoration.

verses.text: The next day, he took out two denarii, gave them to the innkeeper, and said, 'Take care of him, and whatever more you spend, I will repay you when I return.'
verses.comment: Two denarii is generous provision—a sign of ongoing care and promise of return. This resembles Christ’s provision for his Church until his Second Coming.

verses.text: 'Which of these three, do you think, proved to be a neighbor to the man who fell among robbers?'
verses.comment: True neighborliness is practical mercy, not status or ritual. The parable teaches inclusive charity as part of the faith’s visible witness.

verses.text: He said, 'The one who showed mercy to him.' Then Jesus said to him, 'Go, and do likewise.'
verses.comment: Love and mercy are sacrificial and active. This command is a perpetual call to all Christians for visible works of mercy.

verses.text: Now as they were going along, he entered a village; and a woman named Martha welcomed him into her house.
verses.comment: Hospitality toward Christ is both spiritual and practical, laying foundations for the necessity of welcoming Jesus into daily life.

verses.text: She had a sister named Mary, who sat at the Lord's feet and listened to his teaching.
verses.comment: Mary’s posture as a disciple reflects humility and attentiveness—the foundation for deeper spiritual growth and deeper encounter with God.

verses.text: But Martha was distracted with much serving. She came up to him and said, 'Lord, do you not care that my sister has left me to serve alone? Tell her to help me.'
verses.comment: Busy service is important but must be balanced with contemplation. The text sets up a natural tension between action and devotion.

verses.text: But the Lord answered her, 'Martha, Martha, you are anxious and troubled about many things,'
verses.comment: Jesus’s gentle correction affirms the value of interior peace and spiritual focus, not anxiety—a call to contemplative union with God.

verses.text: 'But one thing is necessary. Mary has chosen the good portion, which will not be taken away from her.'
verses.comment: Mary’s focus on the Lord points to the primacy of spiritual contemplation above all else—a foundation for true discipleship and unity in faith, rooted in direct encounter with Christ.
